data.title: List of Irish-American Medal of Honor recipients
data.meta_description: The following is a list of Irish-American soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines who were awarded the American military's highest decoration — the Medal of Honor, sometimes referred to as the Congressional Medal of Honor. The Medal of Honor is bestowed "for conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity...
data.text:
Image Name Service Rank Unit Place of action Date of action Notes

—

Allen, James Army Private South Mountain, Maryland September 14, 1862 Single-handed and slightly wounded he accosted a squad of 14 Confederate soldiers bearing the colors of the 16th Georgia Infantry (C.S.A.).

—

Anderson, Robert Navy Quartermaster On board the USS Crusader and the USS Keokuk 1863 Served on board the USS Crusader and the USS Keokuk during various actions of those vessels.

—

Barry, Augustus Army Sergeant Major Unknown 000000001863-01-01-00001863 – 000000001865-01-01-00001865 Gallantry in various actions during the rebellion.[9]

—

Bass, David L. Navy Seaman Fort Fisher, North Carolina January 15, 1865 On board the U.S.S. Minnesota in action during the assault on Fort Fisher, 15 January 1865.

—

Blackwood, William R. D. Army Surgeon Petersburg, Virginia April 2, 1865 Removed severely wounded officers and soldiers from the field while under a heavy fire from the enemy, exposing himself beyond the call of duty, thus furnishing an example of most distinguished gallantry. Bourke, John Gregory Army Private Company E, 15th Pennsylvania Cavalry Murfreesboro, Tennessee December 31, 1862 – January 2, 1863 Gallantry in action.[10]

—

Brady, James Army E-01Private Battle of Chaffin's Farm, Virginia 000000001864-09-29-0000Sep 29, 1864 Capture of flag[9]

—

Brannigan, Felix Army E-01Private Battle of Chancellorsville, Virginia 000000001863-05-02-0000May 2, 1863 Volunteered on a dangerous service and brought in valuable information.

—

Brosnan, John Army Sergeant Company E, 164th New York Infantry Second Battle of Petersburg, Virginia 000000001864-06-17-0000Jun 17, 1864 Rescued a wounded comrade who lay exposed to the enemy's fire, receiving a severe wound in the effort.[9]

—

Buckley, Denis Army E-01Private Battle of Peachtree Creek, Ga. 000000001864-07-20-0000Jul 20, 1864 Capture of flag of 31st Mississippi (C.S.A.).[9]

—

Buckley, John C. Army Sergeant Battle of Vicksburg, Miss. 000000001863-05-22-0000May 22, 1863 Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."[9]

—

Burk, E. Michael Army E-01Private Battle of Spotsylvania Court House, Virginia 000000001864-05-12-0000May 12, 1864 Capture of flag, seizing it as his regiment advanced over the enemy's works. He received a bullet wound in the chest while capturing flag.[9]

—

Burk, Thomas Army Sergeant Battle of Wilderness 000000001864-05-06-0000May 6, 1864 At the risk of his own life went back while the rebels were still firing and, finding Col. Wheelock unable to move, alone and unaided, carried him off the field of battle.[9]

—

Burke, Daniel W. Army First Sergeant Battle of Shepherdstown, Virginia 000000001862-09-20-0000Sep 20, 1862 Voluntarily attempted to spike a gun in the face of the enemy.[9]

—

Callahan, John H. Army E-01Private Battle of Fort Blakely, Ala. 000000001865-04-09-0000Apr 9, 1865 Capture of flag.

—

Campbell, William Army Private Vicksburg, Mississippi May 22, 1863 Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."

—

Carey, Hugh Army Sergeant 82nd New York Infantry Battle of Gettysburg, Pa. 000000001863-07-02-0000Jul 2, 1863 Captured the flag of the 7th Virginia Infantry (C.S.A.), being twice wounded in the effort.[11]

—

Colbert, Patrick Navy Coxswain Aboard the USS Commodore Hull 000000001864-10-31-0000October 31, 1864 Served on board the U.S.S. Commodore Hull at the capture of Plymouth, 31 October 1864[9]

—

Collis, Charles H. T. Army Colonel Petersburg, Virginia December 13, 1862 Gallantly led his regiment in battle at a critical moment.

—

Conlan, Dennis Navy Seaman Aboard the USS Agawam, First Battle of Fort Fisher 000000001864-12-23-0000December 23, 1864 Conlan served on board the U.S.S. Agawam, as one of a volunteer crew of a powder boat which was exploded near Fort Fisher, 23 December 1864.[9]

—

Connor, Thomas Navy Ordinary Seaman Fort Fisher, North Carolina January 15, 1865 On board the U.S.S. Minnesota, in action during the assault on Fort Fisher, 15 January 1865.

—

Connors, James Army Private Battle of Fisher's Hill, Virginia September 22, 1864 Capture of enemy flag.

—

Cooper, John L. M. Navy Coxswain Mobile Bay, Alabama

Mobile, Alabama August 5, 1864

April 26, 1865 Double MOH recipient

—

Corcoran, John Army E-01Private Third Battle of Petersburg, Virginia 000000001865-04-02-0000Apr 2, 1865 Was one of a detachment of 20 picked artillerymen who voluntarily accompanied an infantry assaulting party, and who turned upon the enemy the guns captured in the assault.[12] Corcoran, Thomas E. Navy Landman Vicksburg, Mississippi May 27, 1863 Served on board the U.S.S. Cincinnati during the attack on the Vicksburg batteries and at the time of her sinking

—

Creed, John Army Private Battle of Fisher's Hill, Virginia September 22, 1864 Capture of the enemy flag. Cronin, Cornelius Navy Chief Quartermaster Aboard the USS Richmond, Battle of Mobile Bay 000000001864-08-05-0000August 5, 1864 On board the U.S.S. Richmond in action at Mobile Bay on 5 August 1864[9]

—

Curran, Richard J. Army Assistant Surgeon Antietam, Maryland September 17, 1862 Voluntarily exposed himself to great danger by going to the fighting line there succoring the wounded and helpless and conducting them to the field hospital.

—

Dougherty, Michael Army E-01Private Jefferson, Virginia 000000001863-10-12-0000Oct 12, 1863 At the head of a detachment of his company dashed across an open field, exposed to a deadly fire from the enemy, and succeeded in dislodging them from an unoccupied house, which he and his comrades defended for several hours against repeated attacks, thus preventing the enemy from flanking the position of the Union forces.

—

Dougherty, Patrick Navy Landsman Aboard the USS Lackawanna, Battle of Mobile Bay 000000001864-08-05-0000August 5, 1864 As a landsman on board the U.S.S. Lackawanna, Dougherty acted gallantly without orders when the powder box at his gun was disabled under the heavy enemy fire, and maintained a supply of powder throughout the prolonged action. Dougherty also aided in the attacks on Fort Morgan and in the capture of the prize ram Tennessee.

—

English, Edmund Army First Sergeant Wilderness, Virginia May 6, 1864 During a rout and while under orders to retreat seized the colors, rallied the men, and drove the enemy back.

—

Fallon, Thomas T. Army E-01Private Williamsburg, Virginia 000000001862-05-01-0000May 1862 and 000000001864-06-01-0000Jun 1864 At Williamsburg, Virginia, assisted in driving rebel skirmishers to their main line. Participated in action, at Fair Oaks, Virginia, though excused from duty because of disability. In a charge with his company at Big Shanty, Ga., was the first man on the enemy's works.[6]

—

Fitzpatrick, Thomas Navy Coxswain Aboard the USS Hartford, Battle of Mobile Bay 000000001864-08-05-0000August 5, 1864 As captain of the No. 1 gun on board the flagship U.S.S. Hartford, during action against rebel gunboats, the ram Tennessee and Fort Morgan in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864.

—

Flanagan, Augustin Army Sergeant Battle of Chaffin's Farm, Virginia 000000001864-09-29-0000Sep 29, 1864 Gallantry in the charge on the enemy's works: rushing forward with the colors and calling upon the men to follow him; was severely wounded.

—

Flannigan, James Army E-01Private Nolensville, Tenn. 000000001863-02-15-0000Feb 15, 1863 Was one of a detachment of 16 men who heroically defended a wagon train against the attack of 125 cavalry, repulsed the attack and saved the train.

—

Flynn, Christopher Army E-04Corporal 14th Connecticut Infantry Battle of Gettysburg, Pa. 000000001863-07-03-0000Jul 3, 1863 Capture of flag of 52d North Carolina Infantry (C.S.A.).[11]

—

Flynn, James E. Army Sergeant Battle of Vicksburg, Miss. 000000001863-05-22-0000May 22, 1863 Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party." Horgan, Michael C. Navy Landman Plymouth, North Carolina October 31, 1864 "[D]istinguished himself by a display of coolness when he participated in landing and spiking a 9-inch gun while under a devastating fire from enemy musketry."

—

Horne, Samuel B. Army Captain Fort Harrison, Virginia September 29, 1864 While acting as an aide and carrying an important message, was severely wounded and his horse killed but delivered the order and rejoined his general.

—

Hudson, Michael Marine Corps Sergeant Mobile Bay, Alabama August 5, 1864 On board the U.S.S. Brooklyn during action against rebel forts and gunboats and with the ram Tennessee in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864

—

Kerr, Thomas R. Army Captain Moorefield, West Virginia August 7, 1864 After being most desperately wounded, he captured the colors of the 8th Virginia Cavalry (C.S.A.).

—

Knox, Edward M. Army O-01Second Lieutenant Gettysburg, Pennsylvania 000000001863-07-02-0000Jul 2, 1863 Held his ground with the battery after the other batteries had fallen back until compelled to draw his piece off by hand; he was severely wounded.[13]

—

Laffey, Bartlett Navy Seaman Yazoo City, Mississippi March 5, 1864 Served on board the U.S.S. Marmora off Yazoo City, Miss., 5 March 1864. Landed ashore with his howitzer gun and crew in the midst of battle and contributed to the turning back of the enemy.

—

Logan, Hugh Navy Captain of the Forecastle Mobile Bay, Alabama December 30, 1862 On board the U.S.S. Rhode Island which was engaged in rescuing men from the stricken Monitor in Mobile Bay, on 30 December 1862.

—

Lonergan, John Army Captain 13th Vermont Infantry Gettysburg, Pennsylvania July 2, 1863 Gallantry in the recapture of 4 guns and the capture of 2 additional guns from the enemy; also the capture of a number of prisoners.[11]

—

Madden, Michael Army Private Mason's Island, Maryland September 3, 1861 Assisted a wounded comrade to the riverbank and, under heavy fire of the enemy, swam with him across a branch of the Potomac to the Union lines.

—

Mangam, Richard C. Army Private Battle of Hatcher's Run, Virginia April 2, 1865 Capture of flag of 8th Mississippi Infantry (C.S.A.)

—

Martin II, James Marine Corps Sergeant Mobile Bay, Alabama August 5, 1864 Despite damage to his ship and the loss of several men on board as enemy fire raked her decks, Sgt. Martin fought his gun with skill and courage throughout the furious 2 hour battle which resulted in the surrender of the rebel ram Tennessee and in the damaging and destruction of batteries at Fort Morgan.

—

McAdams, Peter Army E-04Corporal Salem Heights, Virginia 000000001863-05-03-0000May 3, 1863 Went 250 yards in front of his regiment toward the position of the enemy and under fire brought within the lines a wounded and unconscious comrade.[14]

—

McAnally, Charles Army Second Lieutenant Spotsylvania County, Virginia May 12, 1864 In a hand-to-hand encounter with the enemy captured a flag, was wounded in the act, but continued on duty until he received a second wound.

—

McEnroe, Patrick H. Army Sergeant Winchester, Virginia September 19, 1864 Capture of colors of 36th Virginia Infantry (C.S.A.).

—

McHugh, Martin Navy Seaman Aboard the USS Cincinnati, Operations against Vicksburg 000000001863-05-27-0000May 27, 1863 Serving on board the USS Cincinnati during the attack on the Vicksburg batteries and at the time of her sinking, 27 May 1863.[15] Molloy, Hugh Navy Ordinary Seaman Harrisonburg, Louisiana March 2, 1864 Served on board the USS Fort Hindman during the engagement near Harrisonburg, La., 2 March 1864.

—

Monaghan, Patrick Army E-04Corporal Second Battle of Petersburg, Virginia 000000001864-06-17-0000Jun 17, 1864 Recapture of colors of 7th New York Heavy Artillery.

—

Morrison, John G. Navy Coxswain On board the USS Carondelet July 15, 1862 Serving as coxswain on board the USS Carondelet, Morrison was commended for meritorious conduct in general and especially for his heroic conduct and his inspiring example to the crew in the engagement with the rebel ram Arkansas, Yazoo River, 15 July 1862. Mulholland, St. Clair A. Army Major Chancellorsville, Virginia May 4–5, 1863 In command of the picket line held the enemy in check all night to cover the retreat of the Army.

—

Murphy, Dennis Army Sergeant Corinth, Mississippi October 3, 1862 Although wounded three times, carried the colors throughout the conflict.

—

Murphy, Michael C. Army Lieutenant Colonel Battle of North Anna, Virginia May 24, 1864 This officer, commanding the regiment, kept it on the field exposed to the fire of the enemy for 3 hours without being able to fire one shot in return because of the ammunition being exhausted.

—

Nugent, Christopher Marine Corps Sergeant On board the USS Fort Henry June 15, 1863 For his actions while serving on board the USS Fort Henry, Crystal River, Fla., 15 June 1863.

—

O'Beirne, James R. Army Captain Battle of Seven Pines, Virginia May 31-June 1, 1862 Gallantly maintained the line of battle until ordered to fall back.

—

O'Brien, Henry D. Army E-04Corporal Battle of Gettysburg, Pa. 000000001863-07-03-0000Jul 3, 1863 Taking up the colors where they had fallen, he rushed ahead of his regiment, close to the muzzles of the enemy's guns, and engaged in the desperate struggle in which the enemy was defeated, and though severely wounded, he held the colors until wounded a second time.

—

O'Brien, Oliver Navy Coxswain Aboard the USS John Adams 000000001864-11-28-0000November 28, 1864 Served as coxswain on board the U.S. Sloop John Adams, Sullvan's Island Channel, 28 November 1864. Taking part in the boarding of the blockade runner Beatrice while under heavy enemy fire from Fort Moultrie, O'Brien, who was in charge of one of the boarding launches, carried out his duties with prompt and energetic conduct. This action resulted in the firing of the Beatrice and the capture of a quantity of supplies from her.

—

Peter O'Brien Army E-01Private Battle of Waynesboro, Virginia 000000001865-03-02-0000Mar 2, 1865 Capture of flag and of a Confederate officer with his horse and equipment

—

Thomas O'Connell Navy Coal Heaver Aboard the USS Hartford, Battle of Mobile Bay 000000001864-08-05-0000Aug 5, 1864 On board the flagship USS Hartford, during successful attacks against Fort Morgan, rebel gunboats and the ram Tennessee in Mobile Bay on 5 August 1864.

—

Timothy O'Connor Army E-01Private Unknown Unknown Date and place of act not of record in War Department.

—

O'Dea, John Army Private Vicksburg, Mississippi May 22, 1863 Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party"

—

O'Donnell, Menomen Army O-02First Lieutenant Battle of Vicksburg, Mississippi and Fort DeRussey, La. 000000001863-05-22-0000May 22, 1863 and 000000001864-03-14-0000Mar 14, 1864 Voluntarily joined the color guard in the assault on the enemy's works when he saw indications of wavering and caused the colors of his regiment to be planted on the parapet. Voluntarily placed himself in the ranks of an assaulting column (being then on staff duty) and rode with it into the enemy's works, being the only mounted officer present, was twice wounded in battle.

—

O'Donoghue, Timothy Navy Seaman Aboard the USS Signal, Red River Campaign 000000001864-05-05-0000May 5, 1864 Served as boatswain's mate on board the USS Signal, Red River, 5 May 1864.

—

Stephen O'Neill Army E-04Corporal Battle of Chancellorsville, Virginia 000000001863-05-01-0000May 1, 1863 Took up the colors from the hands of the color bearer who had been shot down and bore them through the remainder of the battle.

—

Platt, George C. Army Private Fairfield, Pennsylvania July 3, 1863 Seized the regimental flag upon the death of the standard bearer in a hand-to-hand fight and prevented it from falling into the hands of the enemy.

—

Plunkett, Thomas Army Sergeant Fredericksburg, Virginia December 11, 1862 Seized the colors of his regiment, the color bearer having been shot down, and bore them to the front where both his arms were carried off by a shell. Quinlan, James Army Major Savage's Station, Virginia June 29, 1862 Led his regiment on the enemy's battery, silenced the guns, held the position against overwhelming numbers, and covered the retreat of the 2d Army Corps.

—

Rannahan, John Marine Corps Corporal Fort Fisher, North Carolina January 15, 1865 On board the USS Minnesota in the assault on Fort Fisher, 15 January 1865.

—

Reynolds, George Army Private Winchester, Virginia September 19, 1864 Capture of Virginia State flag.

—

Roantree, James S. Marine Corps Sergeant Mobile Bay, Alabama August 5, 1864 On board the USS Oneida during action against rebel forts and gunboats and with the ram Tennessee in Mobile Bay, 5 August 1864.

—

Ryan, Peter J. Army Private Winchester, Virginia September 19, 1864 With one companion, captured 14 Confederates in the severest part of the battle.

—

Schutt, George Navy Coxswain St. Marks, Florida March 5–6, 1865

—

Sewell, William J. Army Colonel Chancellorsville, Virginia May 3, 1863 For assuming command of the brigade, rallying the troops, and remaining in command though wounded.[6]

—

Smith, William Navy Quartermaster On board the USS Kearsarge January 15, 1865 Served as second quartermaster on board the USS Kearsarge when she destroyed the Alabama off Cherbourg, France, 19 June 1864.

—

Sullivan, James Navy Ordinary Seaman Battle of Fort Fisher, North Carolina 000000001864-12-02-0000December 2, 1864 On board the USS Agawam as one of a volunteer crew of a powder boat which was exploded near Fort Fisher, 2 December 1864.

—

Sullivan, John Navy Seaman USS Monticello 000000001864-06-23-0000Jun 23, 1864 – 000000001864-06-25-0000Jun 25, 1864 Served as seaman on board the USS Monticello during the reconnaissance of the harbor and water defenses of Wilmington, North Carolina 23 to 25 June 1864.

—

Sullivan, Timothy Navy Coxswain USS Louisville Various Served on board the USS Louisville during various actions of that vessel. During the engagements of the Louisville, Sullivan served as first captain of a 9 inch gun and throughout his period of service was "especially commended for his attention to duty, bravery, and coolness in action."

—

Tobin, John M. Army First Lieutenant Malvern Hill, Virginia July 1, 1862 Voluntarily took command of the 9th Massachusetts while adjutant, bravely fighting from 3 p.m. until dusk, rallying and re_forming the regiment under fire; twice picked up the regimental flag, the color bearer having been shot down, and placed it in worthy hands.

—

Walsh, John Army Corporal Battle of Cedar Creek, Virginia October 19, 1864 Recaptured the flag of the 15th New Jersey Infantry.

—

Wells, Thomas M. Army Chief Bugler Battle of Cedar Creek, Virginia October 19, 1864 Capture of colors of 44th Georgia Infantry (C.S.A.).

—

Welsh, Edward Army Private Vicksburg, Mississippi May 22, 1863 Gallantry in the charge of the "volunteer storming party."

—

Welsh, James Army E-01Private Battle of the Crater, Petersburg, Virginia 000000001864-07-30-0000Jul 30, 1864 Bore off the regimental colors after the color sergeant had been wounded and the color corporal bearing the colors killed thereby saving the colors from capture.[12]
